notes:
1. Concept

The Logarithmic Mean Temperature Difference (LMTD) is used to determine the average temperature difference between the hot and cold fluids in a heat exchanger. The temperature difference is not constant along the length of the heat exchanger, so a logarithmic average is required for accurate heat transfer calculations.

The overall heat transfer rate ($q$) in the heat exchanger is then calculated using:

$$q = U A \Delta T_{lm}$$
  • $U$ is the overall heat transfer coefficient (W/m²K).
  • $A$ is the total heat transfer surface area (m²).
  • $\Delta T_{lm}$ is the Logarithmic Mean Temperature Difference (K or °C).

2. LMTD Formulas

The formula for LMTD depends on the flow configuration. Let $\Delta T_1$ and $\Delta T_2$ be the temperature differences at the two ends of the heat exchanger.

$$\Delta T_{lm} = \frac{\Delta T_1 - \Delta T_2}{\ln(\Delta T_1 / \Delta T_2)}$$
  • Parallel-Flow: The hot and cold fluids enter at the same end and flow in the same direction.
    • $$\Delta T_1 = T_{h,in} - T_{c,in}$$ $$\Delta T_2 = T_{h,out} - T_{c,out}$$
  • Counter-Flow: The fluids enter at opposite ends and flow in opposite directions.
    • $$\Delta T_1 = T_{h,in} - T_{c,out}$$ $$\Delta T_2 = T_{h,out} - T_{c,in}$$

For the same inlet and outlet temperatures, the LMTD is always greater for a counter-flow arrangement than for a parallel-flow one, making counter-flow more efficient.

solvedExamples.question: For a given set of inlet and outlet temperatures, which heat exchanger flow arrangement provides the highest LMTD?
solvedExamples.explanation: A counter-flow arrangement maintains a more uniform temperature difference along the length of the heat exchanger, resulting in a higher logarithmic mean temperature difference (LMTD) compared to a parallel-flow arrangement. This makes it more thermodynamically efficient.
